{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3157603,"name":"Bruce Backman","username":"backman68","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ea5d25/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-05T17:42:50.686Z","cooked":"

Our team is trying to get an Xbox controller to rumble using setRumble (Java api), and so far we have had no luck. We’ve tried it on different computers, different controllers, roboRio vs simulation, all of the possible values for rumble type, XboxController and CommandXboxController classes, and various values between 0 and 1 for the rumble value. None of those have caused a rumble. Are we missing something?

Rumble doesn’t work in Simulation - needs a robot. Otherwise this command works for us.
Rumble.txt (1.1 KB)

Make sure you are using DriverStation 23.1. I think the detection of Xbox controllers that was fixed could affect Rumble.

backman68:

no luck. We’ve tried it on different computers, different controllers, roboRio vs simulation, all of the possible values for rumble type, XboxController a

I’m a new programmer, so this might be a little confusing:
I found out that there is multiple classes for the xbox controller, my team just switched to CommandXboxController. However, the rumble is not included in this class. My solution was to make an extended class of CommandXboxController which uses parts from the old controller code to make rumble work. Heres my code:

CommandXboxExtended.java

package frc.robot.team58.util;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.GenericHID.RumbleType;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.button.CommandXboxController;

public class CommandXboxExtended extends CommandXboxController {
public CommandXboxExtended(int port) {
super(port);
}

public void setRumble(RumbleType type, double value) {
this.getHID().setRumble(type, value);
}
}

Please ask if you need any more help!

Or just call getHID().setRumble() outside the class? There’s no need to extend it yourself.
